metadata.title: Nanomaterials for the optical detection of fluoride

sections.text:
Extensive efforts have been made to develop sensitive and selective approaches for F - detection, and a variety of F - sensors have been constructed recently. The burgeoning nanotechnology has provided novel materials for F - analysis due to the extraordinary properties of nanomaterials. In this review, we presented the recent advances of different nanomaterials-based approaches for the optical F - detection via colorimetric, fluorescent and chemiluminescent response, such as gold nanomaterials, CeO2 nanoparticles, semiconductor quantum dots, carbon quantum dots, metal-organic frameworks, upconversion nanoparticles, micellar nanoparticles, polymer dots, SiO2 nanoparticles, graphene oxide. Also, the recent trends and challenges in optical detection of F - with various nanomaterials have been discussed. Keywords: Nanomaterials; Fluoride ions; Optical detection; Colorimetric; Fluorescent; Chemiluminescent
1. Introduction Fluoride ions (F - ) show increasing importance in biological and medical processes for the essential roles in dental health and treatment of osteoporosis. 1, 2 However, the unique property of F - , which is easily absorbed by the body and excreted slowly, has received our attentions. Overexposure to F - can bring about dental fluorosis, kidney

and acute gastric problems. 1, 3, 4 And the debilitating bone disease fluorosis is associated with excess F - in drinking water. 1 Thus, the enforceable drinking water standard for F - was set 4 mg/L (～ 0.21 mM) by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA, USA). 5 Moreover, F - has many military applications including the refinement of uranium, and detection of nerve agent, such as sarin and soman. 1 Therefore, selective and sensitive detection of F - is of great significance.
Over the past decade, numerous analytical methods have been developed for highly sensitive and selective sensing of F - , such as mass spectrometry, electrochemical methods, colorimetric methods, fluorescent methods and so on. 1, 5-7 Among these analytical methods, optical methods have been powerful tools because of the simplicity, low-cost, easy operation and rapid response time. In particular, nanomaterials with unique optical properties provide opportunities to facilitate F - sensing owing to their simplicity, cost-effectiveness and rapidity. Based on the origin of the optical signals of nanomaterials, these optical methods can be divided into colorimetric, fluorescent and chemiluminescent methods. And F - can be successfully detected by utilizing changes of the optical signals including absorbance, fluorescence and chemiluminescence. Recently, many nanomaterials, including gold nanomaterials, semi-conductor quantum dots, carbon quantum dots, gold nanomaterials, CeO2 nanoparticles (CeO2NPs), semiconductor quantum dots (QDs), carbon quantum dots (CQDs), metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs), micellar nanoparticles, polymer dots (Pdots), SiO2 nanoparticles (SiO2NPs), graphene oxide (GO), have been used to design a variety of nanosensors for F - due to their ease of fabrication, low-cost, high sensitivity and good biocompatibility.
In these optical nanosensors for F - , nanomaterials mainly play four roles including signal generator, regulator, carrier and catalyst. Most nanomaterials, such as gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) and fluorescent nanomaterials, act as signal generator for detecting F - according to the change of optical signals caused by F - , yielding lots of colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors for F - . AuNPs and silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) may modulate the fluorescent signal of some fluorescent nanomaterials or small molecular probes to construct novel nanoprobes for F - with high accuracy.

SiO2NPs and GO can serve as carriers for organic fluorescent molecules with poor water solubility, improving their water solubility or shortening the response time of organic probes for F - . CeO2NPs and GO can be also employed as catalysts for sensing F - with excellent performance. As a result, extraordinary achievements have been accomplished in the use of various nanomaterials for sensing F - .
In this review, we systematically presented the recent advances of nanomaterials-based optical sensors for F - in the past decade. The review consisted of three main sections based on the signal readout modes, including colorimetric detection, fluorescent detection and chemiluminescent detection. In each section, the general design principle and applications of various nanomaterials in optical detection of F - were provided. The prospect and future challenges of the development of optical nanosensors for F - were also discussed.

Colorimetric methods have been received great attentions because the analytes can be easily read out with the naked eye or ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectrophotometer. AuNPs, CeO2NPs and GO have been applied for colorimetric detection of F - in aqueous solution. As to AuNPs, the color of the AuNPs solution is very sensitive to the distance among AuNPs. Decreasing of the space or aggregation of AuNPs can bring about an obvious color change from red to blue or purple, which can be easily observed with the naked eyes thanks to their high extinction coefficients and unique size-dependent optical properties. 8-10 By utilizing of the reaction or interaction between F - and ligands, the aggregation or dispersion of AuNPs can be modulated, causing the color change of AuNPs solution, which can be used to sense F - with the naked eye (Figure 1A). Recently, the oxidase activity of CeO2NPs can be boosted by F - , which can rapidly oxidize 2,2’-azino-bis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid)diammonium salt (ABTS), yielding deep green color. Assay of F - can be achieved with the naked eye (Figure 1B). Moreover, the rich carboxyl and hydroxyl groups on the surface of GO endow GO with good water solubility, which can greatly improve the water solubility of F - -specific organosilicon probes and assist to catalyze the reaction between F - and silyl-ether, resulting into a rapid response time. The obvious color change can be also observed with the naked eye (Figure 1C). Therefore, the colorimetric detection of F - can be easily achieved with these nanomaterials. 1.1 Gold nanoparticles AuNPs are one of the most studied nanomaterials and have been widely used to construct a variety of colorimetric nanosensors due to their high extinction coefficients and unique size-dependent optical properties. 8-10 AuNPs have been utilized to sense F - based on the aggregation or dispersion of AuNPs modulated by F - . A colorimetric AuNPs-based probe for F - has been constructed based on a quinone-methide-type of rearrangement reaction to trigger a color change of AuNPs. In the method, F - could remove the silyl moieties from phenol groups on the surface of the synthetic probe, leading to a quinone-methide-type of rearrangement reaction and the release of a dithiol. The released dithiol could induce the aggregation of AuNPs owing to the specific interactions between AuNPs and sulfydryl groups,

producing an obvious color change from red to blue, which could be easily observed with the naked eye. As a result, the detection of F - has been achieved with the linear range of 0.12-1.5 mM and a limit of detection (LOD) of 0.12 mM. 11 However, the practical application was not evaluated and the LOD was a bit high. Liu’s group has developed a colorimetric nanosensor for F - based on the F - -modulated disassembly 4-mercaptopyridine-AuNPs@3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (MPD-AuNP@APTMS). The addition of F - could promote the aggregation of MPD-AuNPs owing to the destruction of the outer protecting layer of the sensing system caused by the specific reaction between F - and Si-O bonds of the outer layer, resulting in a visible color change from red to blue (Figure 2A). The as-prepared MPD-AuNP@APTMS exhibited a linear range of 0.5-7.0 µg/mL and a LOD of 0.45 µg/mL. And the sensing system could successfully discriminate F - in groundwater. 12 Polyacrylate capped AuNPs (PAA-AuNPs) have been synthesized via a sunlight induced simple green route. They found that Al 3+ could selectively cause the aggregation of PAA-AuNPs along with a notable change in color from red to blue. Whereas the presence of F - could prevent Al 3+ from aggregating PAA-AuNPs because of the specific interaction between Al 3+ and F - . The sensing method could effectively identify F - from various interfering ions with a LOD of 2 µM and the linear range of 5-150 µM. The assay was successfully used for sensing of F - in various water samples, and the PAA-AuNPs could adsorb on ZIF@8 (zeolitic imidazolate framework) and on a cotton strip to construct a solid sensor for the detection of F - in aqueous solution. 13 However, the introduction of Al 3+ could bring about environmental pollution due to the toxicity of Al 3+ , thus measurement should be further taken to improve the performance. Moreover, other AuNPs functionalized by specific molecules have been applied for sensing F - . 14, 15 These AuNPs-based nanosensors for F - have been successfully constructed, yet further investigations will continue to increase. 1.2 CeO2 nanoparticles Recently, many researchers have found various nanomaterials enzyme-like activities including peroxidase, oxidase, catalase, superoxide dismutase, haloperoxidase and so on. 16
CeO2NPs are also a kind artificial nanozymes with oxidase and catalase

activities. 17, 18 Recently, Liu’s group first revealed that F - could enhance the oxidase activity of CeO2NPs owing to the fact that F - can modulate surface charge and facilitate electron transfer of CeO2NPs. F - capping can greatly enhance the oxidase activity of CeO2NPs by over 100-fold, and the turnover number could reach 700 in 15 min. On account of the enhancement effect of F - , the sensitive detection of F - was realized with linear range of 0-100 µM and a LOD of 0.64 µM, and no other anions can interfere with the detection of F - . Moreover, the method was successfully applied to sense F - in toothpastes (Figure 2B). 19 The assay provided a new perspective for constructing new nanosensors of F - .

sections.heading: 1.3 Graphene oxide
sections.text:
GO exhibits good water solubility, which can promote the solubility of chemodosimeters in aqueous medium and modulate the properties of chemodosimeters. Thus, the combination of GO and some chemodosimeters could be constructed into nanosensors for F - . Yang’s group has developed a colorimetric F - sensor based on the assembly of a F - -specific 6-(tert-Butyldimethylsilyloxy)-1’,3’,3’-trimethylspiro [chromene- 2,2’-indoline] (SPS) with GO. The cleavage of the Si-O bond caused by F - could trigger the conversion from the closed spiropyran to its opened merocyanine form, resulting in the color change from colorless to orange-yellow with good selectivity over other anions. In the presence of GO, the response time could be shortened from 180 min to 30 min, and LOD was reduced more than 1 order of magnitude compared to the free SPS (Figure 2C). A good linearity between the absorbance and F - concentration ranging from 5.0×10 -6 to 1.0×10 -4 M was observed. The LOD was calculated to be 0.86 µM. 20 In addition, the practical application was evaluated in 1:10 dilution of bovine serum samples. And satisfied results were achieved, which is highly consistent with the results obtained form the traditional F - ion-selective electrode.

To compare the performance of these colorimetric nanosensors, a summary of the research work covering colorimetric nanosensors for F - is in Table 1. In view of the simplicity colorimetric nanosensors, more nanomaterials are still highly desirable for designing simple colorimetric sensors for F - with high sensitivity and selectivity.

sections.heading: 2. Fluorescent detection
sections.text:
Compared with colorimetric probes, fluorescent nanosensors show better sensitivity, which have attracted great interest. Up to now, various nanomaterials, including QDs, CQDs, MOFs, Pdots, UCNPs, micellar nanoparticles, SiO2NPs and GO, have been utilized to fluorescently detect F - . There are three responsive modes for the fluorescent nanosensors of F - , including fluorescence turn-off, fluorescence turn-on and ratiometric response. For the fluorescence turn-off mode, F - can directly quench or decrease the fluorescence of nanomaterials through photoinduced electron transfer (PET) or inner filter effect (IFE) caused by the interaction between F - and organic functional molecules on the surface of nanomaterials or in solution. In the PET mechanism, the interaction or reaction between F - and some functional groups may yield favorable electron acceptors which can capture the excited photoelectron of fluorescent nanomaterials, resulting into fluorescence turn-off. And for the IFE system, new molecules or complexes are produced owing to the interaction or reaction between F - and some small organic molecules caused by hydrogen bonds, the reaction of F - and silyl groups, the interaction of F - with phenylborinic acid, Al 3+ or Eu 3+ . Their absorption spectra may overlap with the fluorescence excitation or emission spectra of fluorescent nanomaterials, as a result, the fluorescence can be quenched due to the IFE effect (Figure 3A). Because the fluorescent intensity is easily disturbed by the surroundings, the results of these fluorescence turn-off nanosensors may not too accurate. For the fluorescence turn-on nanosensors, the accuracy is better than that of the above mentioned nanosensors. The presence of F - can enhance or turn-on the fluorescence because of the interaction between F - and quenching agents or disassembly of nanomaterials caused by F - (Figure 3B). Ratiometric response is another response mode, which can provide more accurate results owing to the presence of reference signal in the sensing system. In the nanosensors with ratiometric response, two fluorescence signals are present in the nanosensors, F - can specifically

enhance or reduce one fluorescence signal, and the other unchanged signal serves as the reference signal. The ratio of two fluorescence signals can be used to accurately quantify F - (Figure 3C). We also observed that fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) were often utilized to design fluorescence turn-on and ratiometric responsive nanosensors for F - , in which fluorescent nanomaterials or organic probes can be assembled into FRET system with AuNPs, AgNPs or deliberately designed small molecules, leading to the fluorescence quenching or producing a fluorescence signal. However, the presence of F - can destroy the FRET system because of the specific interactions or reactions between F - and these functional groups or designed small molecules, yielding fluorescence turn-on or change of fluorescence signal. Therefore, the nanosensors with fluorescence turn-on or ratiometric response are highly desirable for sensing F - .
Figure 3. Illustration for the fluorescent responsive modes of nanomaterials for fluorescent detection of F - . 2.1 Quantum Dots Within the group of fluorescent nanoparticles, QDs are mostly used in various sensors due to their ultrabright and tunable fluorescence. The most studied QDs are based on cadmium chalcogenides (S, Se, Te). 21, 22 Some QDs have been applied for fluorescent detection of F - through PET. A fluorescence turn-on sensor for F - has been developed

using ferrocenyl urea capped CdSe/ZnS QDs. The fluorescence of the functionalized QDs could be quenched by the ligand via PET. However, the addition of F - could restore the fluorescence signal of QDs by modulating the rate of PET between the ferrocene moieties and QDs. Accordingly, a fluorescence turn-on nanosensor for F - was successfully constructed with a good linearity in the range of 0.3-5.6 mM and a LOD of 74 µM. However, the practical application was not explored. 23 Similarly, L-cysteine-Ag-CdS/Ag-ZnS QDs have been designed for sensitive detection of F - via fluorescence turn-on mechanism induced by the interaction between F - and L-cysteine of the surface of QDs. The sensing system showed a good linearity when the concentration of F - was in the range of 0.19-22.8 mg/L and the LOD was about 0.0997 mg/L. 24
By utilizing the F - -modulated assembly and disassembly of QDs, a series of QDs-based probes for F - have been designed. Wang’s group has developed a switchable QDs probe for F - based on the hydrogen bonding-driven aggregation and the F - -triggered disaggregation. Cysteamine-stabilized CdTe QDs easily aggregated due to the hydrogen bonding among QDs, resulting in the fluorescence quenching of QDs. The addition of F - could trigger the disassembly of the aggregates, causing the fluorescence turn-on, which may be attributed to the substitution of NH···N hydrogen bonds by NH···F - hydrogen bonds. The QDs exhibited a rapid and selective response towards F - with a LOD of 5.0 µM. 25 3-aminobenzeneboronic acid capped CuInS2 QDs (APBA-CuInS2 QDs) have been synthesized to construct a near-infrared fluorescence nanosensor for sensing glucose and F - via the specific interaction of boronic acid groups with glucose and F - . The reaction of boronic acid groups with vicinal diols of glucose could induce the aggregation of CuInS2 QDs, as a result, the fluorescence was turned off. However, the introduction of F - could turn on the fluorescence of the APBA-CuInS2 QDs/glucose system because of the interaction between F - and the boronic acid groups. The as-prepared nanosensor could be employed to sense F - in the concentration range of 0.1-700 µM with a LOD of 0.029 µM. And the practicability of the sensing system was also demonstrated in tap water and river water. 26
By taking advantage of the disassembly of QDs-metal ion system triggered by F - ,

different QDs-metal ion systems have been investigated for fluorescent detection of F - . Hexametaphosphate capped CdS QDs have been synthesized for sensing Ca 2+ and F - . Ca 2+ could enhance the fluorescence of CdS QDs owing to of the formation of calcium polyphosphate shell. However, the presence of F - could inhibit the Ca 2+ -induced fluorescence enhancement because of the formation of insoluble calcium fluoride. Thus, the QDs-Ca 2+ system could be used to effectively detect F - with the linear range of 10-300 µM and a LOD of 6 µM. 27 Similarly, 3-mercaptopropanoic acid capped CdTe QDs/Eu 3+ (3-MPA-CdTe QDs/Eu 3+ ) system has been designed for fluorescence turn-on detection of F - . In the sensing system, the interaction between Eu 3+ and the carboxylic acid groups could quench the fluorescence of CdTe QDs. But the addition of F - caused fluorescence turn-on of the sensing system due to the formation of EuF3, which is ascribed to the as higher bonding affinity of Eu 3+ with F - than that of carboxylic acid groups (Figure 4A). The designed system was used to assay F - and exhibited a good linearity in range of 0-50 µg/mL with a LOD of 5 ppm. Moreover, HF vapor could be detected using the sensing system. 28
QDs could be also combined with AuNPs or AgNPs to construct FRET nanosensors for F - . In the FRET system, QDs act as fluorescence donors, and AuNPs or AgNPs serve as the energy acceptors, the emission spectrum of QDs partially or wholly overlaps with the absorption spectrum of AuNPs or AgNPs, the FRET system could be constructed. And the addition of F - could modulate the FRET between QDs and AuNPs or AgNPs, resulting in fluorescence turn-off or turn-on. Tang’s group has proposed a CdTe QDs-AuNPs FRET nanosensor for F - based on the formation of cyclic esters between phenylborinic acid and diol. The presence of F - could destroy the assembly of QDs-AuNPs due to the reaction of F - and borinic acid, resulting in the fluorescence recovery of QDs (Figure 4B). The sensing system displayed a good linear relationship between the fluorescence intensity of QDs and the concentration of F - in the range of 5.0-45 µM with a LOD of 50 nM. And the probe was used to assay F - in macrophages cells and tap water. 29 Thioglycolic acid capped CdTe QDs (TGA-CdTe QDs) and citrate-modified AuNPs could be also constructed into a FRET

sections.heading: 2.2 Carbon quantum dots
sections.text:

of the most important applications. β-cyclodextrin and

calix[4]arene-25,26,27,28-tetrol capped CQDs (β-CD-CQDs and C[4]A-CQDs) have been recently prepared to sense F - based on the fluorescence enhancement of CQDs
synthesized from chitosan gel. The capped β-CD and C[4]A could decrease the fluorescent intensity of CQDs through the non-radiative recombination pathway. In the presence of F - , the fluorescence intensity can be enhanced due to the suppression of anon-radiative process resulted from the formation of β-CD/F - and C[4]A/F - . The β-CD-CQDs and C[4]A-CQDs exhibited linear response to F - concentration in the range of 6.6-56.6 µM and 6.6-50.6 µM, respectively. The LOD was determined to be about 6.6 µM. 33 However, the practicability of the detection system should be further investigated.
By virtue of the specific interaction between F - and some metal ions, some CQDs-metal ions system for fluorescence turn-on sensing F - have been designed. A fluorescent on-off-on nanosensor for F - has been developed based CQDs/Eu 3+ system. The water-soluble carboxylic acid-functionalized CQDs were prepared from citric acid. The addition of Eu 3+ could quench the fluorescence of the CQDs due to the aggregation of CQDs caused by Eu 3+ . In the presence of F - , the fluorescence of CQDs restored because of the formation of EuF3. As a result, the CQDs/Eu 3+ system exhibited good linear response towards F - in the range of 1-25 ppm. Moreover, the practical application of the probe was also demonstrated in a toothpaste sample and the results were comparable with that of ion chromatography. 34 Sun and co-workers have prepared a kind of CQDs with green emission for sensing F - via fluorescence turn-off mechanism. They found that Al 3+ could enhance the fluorescent intensity of CQDs. And the addition of F - could decrease the fluorescence intensity of the CQDs-Al 3+ system due to the strong complexing interaction of F - towards Al 3+ . Based on the fluorescence turn-off mechanism, the detection of F - has been successfully achieved, and a linear range between 0-10 µM and the LOD of 0.14 µM have been achieved. 35 To a certain extent, fluorescent graphene oxide (FGO) can be also classified as CQDs. Gao’s group has proposed a rapid method for sensing F - based on the fluorescent N-doped graphene oxide nanosheets/Fe 3+ system. In the sensing system, the fluorescence of the N-doped graphene oxide nanosheets could be

quenched by Fe 3+ , and the addition of F - could recover the fluorescence of the fluorescent graphene nanosheets because of the strong binding affinity between F - and Fe 3+ . Thus, a fluorescence turn-on probe for F - was successfully constructed. And the sensing system could be conducted on paper for visual detection of F - with the LOD down to 1 pM. 36
Meanwhile, a reusable fluorescent sensor for F - has been designed using CQD as fluorophore and EDTA-Ni complex functionalized silica coated magnetite as F - receptor. The binding of CQDs onto the magnetic receptor could reduce the fluorescence intensity of CQDs. Whereas, the addition of F - could recover the fluorescence of CQDs due to the release of CQDs resulted from the specific binding of F - to Ni 2+ of magnetic receptor. The linear response range of F - was found to be 1-20 µM with a LOD of 0.06 µM. The application of the detection system was evaluated with tap water, and the detection system worked quite well in tap water with the recovery of 96%. Meanwhile, the reusability was also tested and the removal of F - was also demonstrated due to the magnetic property and superparamagnetic nature of the receptor. Moreover, the sensing system was successfully utilized for sensing and imaging and of F - in living cells owing to their good cell permeability and low cytotoxicity. 37
CQDs-organic receptor system has been also designed for detection of F - . By virtue of the specific interaction between boronic acid and F - , Safavi’s group has developed a CQDs/4-mercaptophenylboronic acid (MPBA) (CQDs/MPBA) system for sensing F - via the fluorescence turn-off mechanism caused by PET. In the sensing system, the CQDs acted as the fluorophore, and MPBA was used as organic receptor with quenching ability of the fluorescence of CQDs due to the selective interaction F - with the boronic acid and sulfydryl group of MPBA. There was a linear response between the fluorescence intensity and F - concentration ranging from 0 to 26.7 mM, and the LOD was 0.11 mM. The applicability of this system was also tested with spiked river water, and the recoveries were satisfactory. 38 Similarly, arylboronic acids were also used as the organic receptor to construct a CQDs-organic receptor system for fluorescence turn-off sensing F - through IFE between CQDs and fluorinated

arylboronic acids. The sensing system showed a linear response to F - in the range of 0-15 mM and a LOD of 0.146 mM. 39 The CQDs-organic receptor system exhibits simplicity for sensing F - . However, some efforts should be made to enhance the sensitivity and practical applications.
FGO could be combined with AgNPs to construct a FRET system to sense F - in aqueous medium. FGO and phenylborinic acid capped AgNPs could be assembled into the FRET system via the formation of cyclic esters between phenylborinic acid and diol, leading to the fluorescence quenching of FGO. However, the presence of F - could recover the fluorescence of FGO because of the destruction of FRET caused by the formation of trifluoroborate. A good linear correlation existed between the ratio I/I0 and the concentration of F - in the range of 0.05-0.55 nM. The LOD was estimated to be 9.07 pM. Based on the above phenomena, a paper sensor for F - was successfully developed, and as low as 0.1 µM F - was observed with the naked eye. 40 In addition, the sensing system was successfully utilized to detect F - in tap water.

2016, the Royal Society of Chemistry. 2.3 Metal-organic frameworks MOFs, newly developed porous materials, have exhibited great applications in sensors, gas storage, catalysis, gas/vapor separation, bioimaging, drug delivery and so on. 41-44 Fluorescent MOFs have received much attention owing to their outstanding photophysical properties and wide applications. 43,44 Boric-acid-functional lanthanide MOFs have been prepared with 5-boronoisophthalic acid (5-bop) and Eu 3+ under solvothermal condition. The as-prepared MOFs exhibited dual emission at 366 nm and 625 nm with the antenna effect at the single excitation of 275 nm due to the presence of boric acid and Eu 3+ . The selective interaction between F - and boric acid of MOFs could reduce the fluorescent intensity at 625 nm and increase the fluorescent intensity at 366 nm, resulting in a ratiometric nanosensor for F - with a linear range from 4 µM to 80 µM and a LOD of 2 µM (Figure 6A). 45 The reliability of the MOFs for sensing F - has been validated. Recently, an extremely stable Tb-MOFs was synthesized with Tb 3+ and 1,1’-biphenyl]-2,3,3’,5’-tetracarboxylic acid through a simple hydrothermal method. The Tb-MOFs showed bright green luminescence and selective response to F - via fluorescence turn-off mechanism due to the F - -caused collapse of the crystal framework of Tb-MOF. The LOD of Tb-MOF for sensing F - was calculated to be about 0.497 mM, which is a little high. 46 However, the linear relationship was not obtained. A novel Cu-MOFs ([Cu4I(TIPE)3]·3I, TIPE=tetra(3-imidazoylphenyl)ethylene), have been constructed in the presence of sulfosalicylic acid via a simple hydrothermal strategy. The Cu-MOFs exhibited blue emission and selective response to F - through fluorescence turn-off mechanism due to the substitution of I - by F - and the F - ···H–C hydrogen bond interactions with the framework. As a result, the LOD towards F - was determined to be 2.11 µM, and the linear scope covered the range of 10-70 µM. 47 However, other halogen anions with high concentration interfere with the assay of F - . Recently, fluorescein sodium (FS) incorporated in the zirconium-based MOFs (FS@UiO-66) was successfully prepared via the in-situ synthesis approach. The FS@UiO-66 could be used to selectively and rapidly sense F - in aqueous solution. In the sensing system, the specific combination

sections.heading: 2.4 Polymer dots
sections.text:
As a brightly emissive nanomaterial, Pdots have become a research hotspot in fields of sensors, bioimaging, diagnosis and therapies owing to their excellent fluorescence brightness, good photostability, and low cytotoxicity. 49, 50 Recently, a coumarin-doped Pdots nanosensors have been designed for ratiometric detection of F - using tert-butyldiphenylsilyl(TBDPS)-protected 7-hydroxy-4-tri-fuoromethyl coumarin encapsulated poly(2,5-di(3’,7’-dimethyloctyl)phenylene-1,4-ethynylene) (PPE). In the sensing system, F - can cause the deprotection of the tert-butyldimethylsilyl group on coumarin to induce FRET from PPE to coumarin, resulting in the fluorescence color change from blue to green. The ratiometric responsive behavior of F - to the Pdots provided the accurate detection of F - in aqueous solution with a linear range of 0-160 µM. Meanwhile, the Pdots have been applied for sensing F - in live cells. 50 In the detection system, the blue fluorescence from PPE is very close to the green emission of coumarin, which is difficult to distinguish. Further improvement is still required. Zhao et al. have developed a reaction-based fluorescent/phosphorescent dual-emissive Pdots for rapidly sensing F - in water and biological systems by employing a dual-emissive conjugated polyelectrolyte P1 containing phosphorescent iridium(III) complex. The F - -responsive tertbutyldiphenylsilyl moiety in the iridium(III) complex with red emission was used as the signaling unit for sensing F - . In the absence of F - , the Pdots exhibited moderate blue emission centered at 420 nm from polyfluorene and the stronger red phosphorescence at about 600 nm from iridium(III) complex. Upon the addition of F - , the red phosphorescence at 600 nm decreased drastically, whereas, the blue emission at 420 nm changed little. Based on the ratiometric response of F - , an accurate nanoprobe for F - with a linear range from 5 to 13 µM and a LOD of 7.0 ppb could be constructed. The Pdots have been also applied for sensing F - in live cells (Figure 6B). 51 Bai’s group has prepared a Pdots with red emission based on the assembly of amonochelic polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS)-containing

The Pdots could be used to sense F - by virtue of the F - -catalyzed hydrolysis of POSS to induce the self-quenching of PBI. In view of the fluorescence turn-off mechanism, the Pdots could detect as low as 10 µM F - and the linear range is 0-100 µM. 52 These Pdots could be utilized to sense F - with high accuracy, however, the preparation of Pdots is too complicated. Thus, it is expected more simple synthetic approaches of Pdots will be available in the coming years.

convert near-infrared light to visible light, reducing autofluorescence and light scattering and resulting in promising applications in sensors, bioimaging, biomedical fields. 53-55 A ratiometric fluorescence and colorimetric nanosensor for F - has been constructed by utilizing IFE between amino modified UCNPs and curcumin-F - complex. In the detection system, the Yb 3+ , Er 3+ , and Tm 3+
codoped NaYF4 UCNPs
emitted fluorescence at 546, 657, 758, and 812 nm under the 980 nm single wavelength excitation. And the absorption spectrum of the curcumin-F - complex overlapped with the upconversion fluorescence of UCNPs at 546 and 637 nm, resulting in the fluorescence quenching at 546 and 657 nm, whereas the emission at 758 and 812 nm remained unchanged. As a result, a ratiometric fluorescence nanosensor for F - with the linear range of 5-200 µM and a LOD of 5 µM was constructed based on the fluorescence ratio I546/I758 was inversely proportional to the F - concentration. Meanwhile, the addition of F- could also cause the large absorption bathochromic shift, resulting into a color change. Accordingly, a colorimetric analysis of F - by the naked eye could be also achieved with the linear range of 25-200 µM and a LOD of 25 µM (Figure 7A). 55 In the sensing system, the introduction of curcumin is the key for constructing the nanosensor, and the ratiometric fluorescence nanosensor for F - possessed high accuracy. It is therefore highly desirable to design more simple UCNPs-based nanosensors for F - . 2.6 Micellar Nanoparticles Micellar nanoparticles have been widely utilized in a variety of fields including sensor, drug and gene delivery. 56-58 A fluorescent micellar nanoparticles has been synthesized for ratiometric fluorescent sensing F - via the self-assembly of P(MMA-co-NBDAE)-b-PF-b-P-(MMA-co-NBDAE) coil-rod-coil triblock copolymer, where MMA, NBDAE, and PF are methyl methacrylate, 4-(2-acryloyloxyethylamino)-7-nitro-2,1,3-benzoxadiazole, and polyfluorene, respectively. In the absence of F - , the micellar nanoparticles emitted green fluorescence due to the effective FRET from the blue emitted PF to NBDAE with green emission. However, the presence of F - could remove FRET between them owing to the effective interaction between F - and NBDAE, resulting in blue emission.

sections.heading: 2.7 Silicon dioxide nanoparticles
sections.text:
SiO2NPs, a low toxic nanomaterial, can be used as nanocarriers of fluorescent dyes for indentifying F - in aqueous solution. Based on the specific reaction between F - and Si-O bonds, a F - specific silyl-ether protected fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) was immobilized on the surface of 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTES) and 3-[2-(2-aminoethylamino)ethylamino] propyltrimethoxysilane (APAEAETMS) modified SBA-15, forming sensors ASBA and TSBA. The presence of F - led to the distinct changes in absorption and emission spectra because of the cleavage of Si-O bonds caused by F - . The fluorescence intensity linearly increased with F - concentration ranging from 0.2 µM to 0.75 µM. The LOD of TSBA and ASBA were estimated to be 0.02 µM and 0.50 µM, respectively. The proposed nanosensors showed great selectivity over other common anions. 60 Similarly, silyl-ether protected fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC-OSMDBT) was also modified on the surface of two different amino-silane molecules functionalized SiO2NPs for selectively sensing F - . The researchers found that amino-silane molecules on the surface of SiO2NPs exhibited great effect on the linear range and LOD of the nanosensors as the amino-silane molecules can alter the loading amount of FITC-OSMDBT on the surface of SiO2NPs, which in turn regulated the emission spectra of the nanosensor through non-radiative emission energy transfer mechanisms. Moreover, the detection of F - was carried out in DMSO solution, the performance requires further improvement and their applications in aqueous solution still needs to be demonstrated. 61 In addition, 7-nitro-2,1,3-benzoxadiazole (NBD) was also immobilized on the surface of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MCM-41) to construct a fluorescent nanosensor for F - . The fluorescence of NBD in the MCM-41 could be quenched because of the aggregation caused quenching (ACQ) phenomenon. However, the presence of F - could cause the cleavage of Si-O bonds, resulting in the release of NBD and more than six-fold fluorescence enhancement. The working range of concentration for determination of F - was calculated to be 10 -5 M to 10 -3 M, and the

response time can be as low as 40 min. 62
By virtue of the formation of hydrogen bonds between F - and hydrogen atoms of some groups, a nanosensor for F - has been developed based on organic-inorganic hybrid nanomaterials containing anthraquinone. Anthraquinone-based fluorescent receptor was immobilized on mesoporous silica (AFMS) or on silica particles (AFSP) via a sol-gel reaction. The presence of F - caused a large decrease in the fluorescence intensity of the anthraquinone of AFMS due to the binding of F - to two urea N-H protons of receptor in AFMS. And other anions did not decrease the fluorescence of AFMS. The fluorescence intensity of AFMS showed a good linearity versus F - concentration in the range of 0.50-10.0 µM, and the LOD was about 0.5 µM. The sensitivity of AFMS was 10 times higher than that of AFSP because of its large surface area of the mesoporous SiO2NPs. 63 Similarly, 1-naphthylamine was also immobilized on the surface of mesoporous SiO2NPs via 3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl isocyanate for sensing F - in aqueous medium. The hydrogen bond interactions between F - and amide units could reduce the fluorescent intensity of probe, and the LOD was about 8.74 µM. 64 To improve the sensitivity, a novel lanthanide fluorescent mesoporous nanoprobe was designed for fluorescence turn-off sensing of F - . The polydentate type ligand derived from N 2 ,N 6 -bis(4,4-diethoxy-9-oxo-3-oxa-8,10-diaza-4-siladodecan-12-yl)pyridine-2,6-dic arboxamide and Eu 3+ /Tb 3+
was immobilized on the surface of mesoporous SiO2NPs
(MSNs-Eu and MSNs-Tb). The interactions of the ligand and Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ could result in red and green emission, respectively. However, the addition of F - could quench the fluorescence because of the strong hydrogen bonding interaction between F - and the ligand. A good linear response was observed with F - concentration ranging from 10 -6 to 10 -5 M. The LOD for MSNs-Eu and MSNs-Tb were 0.025 µM and 0.034 µM, respectively (Figure 8A). 65

sections.heading: 2.8 Graphene oxide
sections.text:
GO exhibits no fluorescence in aqueous solution, but with the aid of GO, the sensing and bioimaging performance of some fluorescent chemodosimeters can be improved. A F - -specific fluorescent chemodosimeter (FC-A) has been prepared and assembled

on the GO to construct a GO/FC-A system for sensing F - in aqueous solution. FC-A showed the weak fluorescence emission with a peak maximum at 515 nm. However, F - could react with FC-A, forming IC-B, which exhibited strong fluorescent emission centered at 521 nm. In view of the chemical catalysis and nanocarrier functions of GO, the GO/FC-A system showed rapid response time, which was shortened from 4 h to 30 min. And the sensitivity of GO/FC-A system was more than 2-fold higher than that of the free FC-A. A good linear relationship between the ratio I/I0 and F - concentration ranging from 2.0 to 90 µM was observed and the LOD was estimated to be about 0.3 µM. And the GO/FC-A system exhibited better bioimaging performance than FC-A due to the nanocarrier function of GO for cells. In addition, the practical application of the CO/FC-A system for sensing F - has been explored in river water (Figure 8B). 66 Similarly, a novel silicon-oxygen aurone derivative TBDPSA was combined with GO to form GO/TBDPSA system for detection of F - in aqueous solution. The GO/TBDPSA system showed higher sensitivity and rapid response time for F - when compared with TBDPSA in aqueous solution due to the catalytic effect from GO. In the presence of GO, the GO/TBDPSA of the response rate increased greatly and the response time was less than 5 s. And the LOD was 0.058 µM with fluorescence as detected signal. 67 The GO/dye system exhibited good performance for the assay of F - , but the fluorescence quenching effect of GO for fluorescent dye can not been ignored. Thus, for the GO/dye system, there are many issues should be addressed before the further applications.

sections.heading: 3. Chemiluminescent detection
sections.text:
Chemiluminescence (CL) detection has been widely used in various fields owing to its low cost, simplicity and high sensitivity. 68-71 Gold nanoparticles and silver nanoparticles have been found to enhance the CL of the permanganate-aldehydes system. Similarly, gold nanoprisms (AuNPRs) can also enhance the CL of KMnO4-glutaraldehyde. And the simultaneous addition of F - and Fe 3+ could greatly increase in CL intensity. Based on the enhancing effect, F - could be sensitive determined with a linear range of 0.18-268 µM and a LOD of 0.043 µM. The method was further applied to detect F - in urine and tap water, and satisfactory results have

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion and future perspectives
sections.text: This review focuses on nanosensors for optical detection of F - based on the colorimetric, fluorescent and chemiluminescent response. A variety of nanomaterials included in the review are AuNPs, CeO2NPs, QDs, CQDs, MOFs, Pdots, UCNPs, micellar nanoparticles, SiO2NPs, GO and so on. These approaches utilize the unique optical or catalytic properties associated with nanomaterials. The present advances described in the review demonstrated that nanomaterials exhibited promising applications for optical detection of F - , however, several challenges are still remained. First, more optical nanosensors for F - with ratiometric response are highly desirable because more accurate analytical results can be achieved. Second, the practical applications of these nanosensors for F - in complex matrixes including cell lysates and biological fluids should be further investigated, which may be beneficial for human health. Third, optical nanosensors with more robustness are pressingly needed owing to the complexity of practical samples. Last but not the least, development of optical nanosensors with dual functions of sensing and removing of F - is of great significance for human beings and the environment. The present nanosensors are only used to detect F - , can not remove F - . However, optical nanosensors with dual functions can both sense and remove F - simultaneously, achieving dual proposes of the detection and removal of F - . With burdening development of nanotechnology, more robust nanosensors with high accuracy will be constructed for the optical detection of F - in practical samples in the coming years.

13 calix[4]arene-25,26,27,28-tetrol capped CQDs (β-CD-CQDs and C[4]A-CQDs) have been recently prepared to sense F based on the fluorescence enhancement of CQDs
The capped β-CD and C[4]A could decrease the fluorescent intensity of CQDs through the non-radiative recombination pathway.

metadata.abstractText: Overexposure of fluoride ions (F ) causes serious diseases to human beings. Extensive efforts have been made to develop sensitive and selective approaches for F detection, and a variety of F sensors have been constructed recently. The burgeoning nanotechnology has provided novel materials for F analysis due to the extraordinary properties of nanomaterials. In this review, we presented the recent advances of different nanomaterials-based approaches for the optical F detection via colorimetric, fluorescent and chemiluminescent response, such as gold nanomaterials, CeO2 nanoparticles, semiconductor quantum dots, carbon quantum dots, metal-organic frameworks, upconversion nanoparticles, micellar nanoparticles, polymer dots, SiO2 nanoparticles, graphene oxide. Also, the recent trends and challenges in optical detection of F with various nanomaterials have been discussed.
